prior_works.title: Calibrating Noise to Sensitivity in Private Data Analysis
prior_works.authors: Cynthia Dwork; Frank McSherry; Kobbi Nissim; Adam Smith
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the formal definition of (edge) differential privacy and the Laplace/sensitivity toolkit that enables turning min s–t cut objectives (with unit sensitivity under edge-adjacency) into private selection procedures without asymptotic runtime overhead.

prior_works.title: Mechanism Design via Differential Privacy
prior_works.role: Exponential mechanism for private combinatorial selection
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces the exponential mechanism, directly enabling the paper’s private near-min-cut selection by scoring cuts via (negative) cut size and sampling/argmin with noise, thereby matching non-private runtimes up to negligible overhead.

prior_works.title: Boosting and Differential Privacy
prior_works.authors: Cynthia Dwork; Guy N. Rothblum; Salil Vadhan
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies the advanced composition theorem that forms the natural privacy-accounting baseline when repeatedly invoking private s–t cut routines for multiway k-cut; the paper’s main multiway algorithm achieves guarantees exponentially better (in k) than this compose-all-calls baseline.

prior_works.title: The Composition Theorem for Differential Privacy
prior_works.authors: Peter Kairouz; Sewoong Oh; Pramod Viswanath
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Gives optimal composition bounds refining advanced composition; the new multiway k-cut algorithm is contrasted against the best-known composition accounting, highlighting its superior (in k) privacy scaling over composing many private s–t cuts.

prior_works.title: Multi-terminal Network Flows
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the all-pairs min-cut tree structure that underlies reducing multi-terminal separation to a small, structured set of s–t cuts; the paper leverages such structure to orchestrate few private min-cut invocations and avoid naive composition blowup.

prior_works.title: The Complexity of Multiway Cuts
prior_works.authors: Egon Dahlhaus; David S. Johnson; Christos H. Papadimitriou; Paul D. Seymour; Mihalis Yannakakis
prior_works.role: Algorithmic template for multiway cut via isolating s–t cuts
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes the multiway k-cut problem and the isolating-cuts based 2-approximation that reduces to k calls to s–t min-cut; the paper privatizes and improves the privacy accounting of this template compared to straightforward composition.

prior_works.title: A Multiplicative Weights Mechanism for Privacy-Preserving Data Analysis
prior_works.role: General DP methodology and lower-bound intuition
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides a general framework for privately answering large families of linear queries (including cut queries) and informs accuracy/privacy trade-offs and packing-style lower-bound techniques that the paper adapts to obtain nearly tight bounds for private min-cut.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution—nearly tight lower and upper bounds for differentially private min s–t cut and a private multiway k-cut algorithm with superior privacy scaling—builds on three intertwined lines of work. First, foundational differential privacy machinery (Dwork–McSherry–Nissim–Smith) and the exponential mechanism (McSherry–Talwar) supply the template to privatize combinatorial selection problems like min-cut. Because the s–t cut objective has bounded edge sensitivity, perturb-and-select strategies or exponential-mechanism-style scoring can output near-optimal cuts while preserving almost the same runtime as standard max-flow/min-cut algorithms, realizing the paper’s “privacy at no runtime cost.” Second, composition theorems (Dwork–Rothblum–Vadhan; Kairouz–Oh–Viswanath) define the natural baseline for multiway k-cut: running a private s–t cut routine multiple times and composing privacy losses. The paper departs from this by exploiting graph structure to reduce the number and arrangement of private invocations, thereby achieving privacy guarantees that improve exponentially in k relative to naive advanced composition. Third, classical structure for cuts and multiway separation (Gomory–Hu trees; Dahlhaus et al.’s isolating cuts) enables turning multi-terminal separation into a carefully controlled set of s–t cut computations on a laminar/structured family of cuts, which is crucial for tight privacy accounting and improved utility. Finally, general DP optimization frameworks and lower-bound techniques (Hardt–Rothblum) inform the paper’s near-tight accuracy lower bounds, aligning the achievable utility of their private min-cut procedures with principled limitations.
